definition:
Let $c$ be a circle with diameter $OA = a$. Set a tangent line $t$ of
the circle at the point $A$. For any point $C$ of $c$ let $P$ be the
intersection point of the secant line $OC$ and the tangent line $t$.
Determine on the secant line between $O$ and $P$ the point $Q$ such that
$$PQ \;=\; OC.$$ Then the locus of the point $Q$ is the [*cissoid of
Diocles*]{}. The name is derived from Greek
$\varkappa\iota\sigma\sigma\acute{o}\varsigma$ (kissos) ‘ivy’,
$\varepsilon\iota\delta{o}\varsigma$ (eidos) ‘form, kind, type’.

The cissoid is symmetric with regard to the line $OA$, having at $O$ a
cusp. The line $t$ is the asymptote of the curve.

For deriving the equation of the cissoid, chose the ray $OA$ for the
positive $x$-axis. Let $\varphi$ be the slope angle (polar angle) of any
$C$ on $c$. From the triangle $OAP$ we see that
$\displaystyle OP = \frac{a}{\cos\varphi}$. Since $\angle ACO$ is a
right angle, we have $OC = a\cos\varphi$. It follows that
$\displaystyle OQ = r = \frac{a}{\cos\varphi}-a\cos\varphi$, that is,
$$\begin{aligned}
r \;=\; a\sin\varphi\tan\varphi.\end{aligned}$$ For obtaining the
equation in rectangular coordinates, we may write (1) as
$r^2 = (r\sin\varphi)\,a\tan\varphi$, i.e.
$\displaystyle x^2\!+\!y^2 = ya\cdot\frac{y}{x}$, whence
$(x^2\!+\!y^2)x = ay^2$, or $$\begin{aligned}
y \;=\; \pm{x}\,\sqrt{\frac{x}{a\!-\!x}}.\end{aligned}$$ Thus it’s a
question of an algebraic curve. The cissoid has also the parametric
presentation $$\begin{aligned}
x \;=\; \frac{au^2}{1\!+\!u^2}, \quad y \;=\; \frac{au^3}{1\!+\!u^2}.\end{aligned}$$

**Note.** If we apply the inversion formulae
$$x \;\mapsto\; \frac{x}{x^2\!+\!y^2}, \quad y \;\mapsto\; \frac{y}{x^2\!+\!y^2}$$
(where $r = 1$) to the parabola $y = \pm\sqrt{x}$, we get as the image
of the parabola the cissoid
$\displaystyle{y} = \pm{x}\,\sqrt{\frac{x}{1-x}}$; correspondingly the
image of this cissoid is that parabola.
